Nature is full of surprises. Meet Costasiella kuroshimae, an adorable species of sea slug known as “leaf sheep.”

At no more than 8mm, these tiny ocean critters graze on algae & keep chloroplasts in their bodies for up to 10 days. They supplement their diet through photosynthesis to create energy, which is why they’re sometimes referred to as “solar-powered sea slugs.” https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20210324-the-odd-sea-creature-powered-by-the-sun #nature #science

What can Lego teach us about how to save the planet?
Large complex projects have a habit of going wrong - sometimes catastrophically wrong. Just ask Dan Gardner and Bent Flyvbjerg, authors of the well-worth-your-time new book "How Big Things Get Done"
https://www.amazon.com/How-Big-Things-Get-Done/dp/0593239512/ref=sr_1_1?keywords=how+big+things+get+done&qid=1674813091&sprefix=how+big+%2Caps%2C178&sr=8-1

if anyone's wondering, i got semi nerdsniped again by "transactional mutex locks"

http://people.csail.mit.edu/shanir/publications/2009_TRANSACT_TML.pdf

it's a single writer lock that's never blocked by a reader. the tldr is "you keep a global epoch, readers wait for it to be even, and check it's unchanged at the end, writers wait for it to be even, and increment it before and after their work"

thing is, if you're a bit fancy, you could probably get readers to check for conflicts if they're interrupted by a writer
